Styling text
Sometimes it might be necessary to use different text formatting to indicate hierarchy or prominence. Follow these tips to keep readability top of mind when styling and formatting text.

Use sentence case when writing, it fits most contexts. Donât use all caps to get a userâs attention because itâs difficult to read. See the content design guidance for more information.
Write in sentence case
Avoid using all caps
Alignment
Fluent uses baseline alignment to distribute vertical space. This creates a consistent visual rhythm within a layout.
When aligning text horizontally, generally stick to left-alignment for left-to-right (LTR) languages, like English.
Use right-alignment for right-to-left (RTL) languages, like Arabic or Hebrew, or to distinguish a short text element in English, like a side note. Donât right-align long blocks of text in LTR languages.
Use the same discretion when centering text. It should call attention to a small piece of copy, or support another element on the page.
Color
Applying color can emphasize or de-emphasize text. Using a primary color on text will give it more visual prominence than the standard text color. In contrast, using a lighter neutral than standard text will subdue the text and place it lower in a visual hierarchy.
Be sure to follow the color guidelines when applying color to text.
Standard text must have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 against its background. Large text (above 18.5 pixels bold, or 24 pixels regular) must have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. Use these resources to make sure your designs pass color contrast and other accessibility considerations.

# Typography

Clear typographical hierarchy organizes and structures content, making it easy for people to find their way through an experience.

![](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-overview.DKm36uVz.webp&w=1536&h=940&f=png)

---

## Fluent font stacks

### Segoe - unmistakably Microsoft

Friendly and legible, Segoe is Microsoftâs signature typeface. It emphasizes readability and personality at different sizes. Variants of Segoe are used across Windows OS, Win UI native apps, and web apps.

![Segoe](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-segoe.Bvq3H4k0.webp&w=1536&h=440&f=png)

### Native type on every platform

While Segoe UI is Fluentâs primary typeface, the system defaults to native system fonts to ensure a familiar and accessible experience across platforms.

![Type on Windows, Web, macOS, iOS and Android](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-native.mZZMyyvq.webp&w=1536&h=440&f=png)

---

## Styling text

Sometimes it might be necessary to use different text formatting to indicate hierarchy or prominence. Follow these tips to keep readability top of mind when styling and formatting text.

### Casing

Use sentence case when writing, it fits most contexts. Donât use all caps to get a userâs attention because itâs difficult to read. See the content design guidance for more information.

![Typography casing do](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-letter-casing-do.CDJmmnpw.webp&w=728&h=440&f=png)

Write in sentence case

![Tyopgrahy casing don't](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-letter-casing-dont.wXGxrB8V.webp&w=728&h=440&f=png)

Avoid using all caps

### Alignment

Fluent uses baseline alignment to distribute vertical space. This creates a consistent visual rhythm within a layout.

![Type on Windows, Web, macOS, iOS and Android](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-alignment-vert.DhUJXCno.webp&w=1536&h=840&f=png)

When aligning text horizontally, generally stick to left-alignment for left-to-right (LTR) languages, like English.

![Type on Windows, Web, macOS, iOS and Android](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-alignment-horz.CWksIAKs.webp&w=1536&h=840&f=png)

Use right-alignment for right-to-left (RTL) languages, like Arabic or Hebrew, or to distinguish a short text element in English, like a side note. Donât right-align long blocks of text in LTR languages.

Use the same discretion when centering text. It should call attention to a small piece of copy, or support another element on the page.

![Typography casing do](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-alignment-do-1.JWTwC7BN.webp&w=728&h=440&f=png)

![Tyopgrahy casing don't](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-alignment-do-2.B3_i8_GM.webp&w=728&h=440&f=png)

### Color

Applying color can emphasize or de-emphasize text. Using a primary color on text will give it more visual prominence than the standard text color. In contrast, using a lighter neutral than standard text will subdue the text and place it lower in a visual hierarchy.

Be sure to follow the color guidelines when applying color to text.

![Type on Windows, Web, macOS, iOS and Android](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-color-1.DkGHzP3I.webp&w=1536&h=1020&f=png)

Standard text must have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 against its background. Large text (above 18.5 pixels bold, or 24 pixels regular) must have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. Use these resources to make sure your designs pass color contrast and other accessibility considerations.

![Type on Windows, Web, macOS, iOS and Android](/_image?href=https%3A%2F%2Ffluent2websitecdn.azureedge.net%2Fcdn%2Ftypography-color-2.DaA-NGkw.webp&w=1536&h=740&f=png)
